5 Reasons Why India Is the Dirtiest and the Most Polluted Country in The World

What is the first thing that comes to your mind when you hear India? Most people will answer cows, toilets, Bollywood, the Taj Mahal, and high rape rates.

All these assessments are not wrong, considering that this country, which is located at the South Asian region has more negative sides than positive sides.

India is known as a backward and outdated country. Its social problems are very complex.

Apart from the issue of rape, most parts of India are slums, which impress people from all over the world, that they are filthy and dirty. This is also proven by surveys from various research institutions which place India at the top of the list of the dirtiest countries with the highest levels of pollutants in the world.

5 reasons India is the most polluted country

1. Poverty

India often boasts about its rapid economic development, but a survey by the Rangarajan Committee shows that more than 38% of the population live below the poverty line in 2023.

With great poverty, most residents live in inappropriate places such as riverbanks, slums.

2. Density

India is one of the most densely populated countries in the world with very limited natural resources compared to its booming population. Its population reaches 1.4 billion.

Poverty and density are the 'right' combination to create a slum and polluted environmental situation. Garbage, human waste, animal waste is strewn everywhere on the streets of India, the large number of vehicles and related things certainly make India look so dirty and filthy.

3. Don't care about the surrounding environment

There is an interesting fact from the primitive lifestyle of Indians. They tend not to care about the surrounding environment.
This is because Indians think that public facilities are the responsibility of other people, especially the government. So even though a lot of rubbish has piled up, even though it disturbs the view and causes an unpleasant smell, it's all left alone. Even though outsiders think this is very sad, Indians, whose mindset is backward and uncivilized, have become accustomed to this situation.

4. Caste Mentality

It is common knowledge that Indian society, which is predominantly Hindu, knows caste in their life. Because of these social norms, people who feel they belong to a higher class tend not to want to do work that is identical to that of people from the strata below them.

5. Government Services

India is a very poor country. This results in minimal government services and attention to environmental issues. Such as widening waterways, emptying trash cans and so on.

I'm sad to hear you had such a negative experience in India - I'm also a solo female traveler in India going on 4 months being here and have loved my time. It did take me awhile to get used to some of the hecticness though. Everyone has a different experience but here are two things other female travelers could possibly keep in mind to prevent this:

1) These problems are often way worse in Jaipur and other big tourist centers. But, this isn't representative of the rest of India. Go to Amritsar, Lucknow, Kolkata, and even Varanasi and some of these issues won't happen or at least not as frequently. I actually think having a guide and driver attracts most of this unwanted behavior (photos, scams, shouting, etc.) and when you're actually fully alone people tend to leave you alone more. If you're determined to go to someplace like Jaipur, I highly recommend going during the off-season for tourism (in the brutal summer heat) because it will be much calmer.

2) There's a difference between being unsafe and being uncomfortable. Based on this video, I don't think there was ever an actual danger risk, even though I totally get it was scary. In my experience, no one is violent or dangerous, they are just overworked, undertrained, and trying to bring money home to their families and you are the unfortunate recipient of the results of that. Even the hotel lock story seems like a classic case of undertrained staff in hotels but I doubt anything malicious was happening. Of course, just like every major city in the world, crime happens in Indian cities, and just because nothing bad has ever happened to me doesn't mean it can't happen. However, I think its important to know that many women do have positive experiences in India and discomfort does not equal danger.

As an Indian, this video left me feeling deeply ashamed. I watched and listened with growing horror to this young lady narrate her harrowing ordeal while she was traveling in India. For whatever little it's worth, I want to apologise to this young woman, Phoebe, for her traumatic experience, and since there is nothing I can really do to mitigate the damage caused to her by the scoundrels she encountered on her tour, I thought I might leave a few suggestions for the future.

For all westerners traveling to India, please make note of the following:

1. If you are a woman, never ever be alone even for a second. It doesn't matter how old you are, or whether you are black or white or anything else. The predators don't discriminate when it comes to abuse, harassment and worse.

Always have some men near you who you feel will be there to stand with you in case you get accosted by predators. I'm sorry, I know that sounds misogynistic and patriarchal, but I'm just saying whatever occurs to me in the interests of safety. Your friends don't even have to be men of your own country, they could be men of any nationality, as long as you feel you can genuinely trust them with your safety and well-being.

2. The moment you feel unsafe, immediately pull out your phone and start taking a video of the people troubling you. That alone might be enough to intimidate any would-be harassers. It may or may not be enough, but it's a start, and it's still better than nothing. This one is actually tricky because I'm fully aware that in a frightening situation this would not occur to most people, as they are too shocked and frightened to respond at all, but if you are prepared for it beforehand, it might be easier to remember in times of crisis.

3. If possible, contact your country's embassy and high commission and seek help the moment something bad happens to you. It might also be a good idea to get in touch with the Indian Police, the government, the Ministry of Tourism etc. Record and document all conversations you have with local authorities, with names and designations if possible. They aren't really going to be very helpful, but again, it's still better than nothing at all, and you never know, someone might decide to step up and take action.

4. Making and sharing Youtube videos like this is an excellent idea. That's one reason I'm commenting here, so that it gets a little more reach. This raises awareness about the situation and ensures that similar or worse things don't happen to other people.

5. Do not, I repeat, DO NOT believe that you are overreacting or being unreasonable, or that you might have possibly done something to provoke this behaviour from other people. You are not responsible for how other people are making you feel. This is especially true of women.

6. If possible, name and shame the people who have harassed you. This one is especially important. It will warn others of who exactly to avoid and what to expect in case anyone runs into these people. Don't be embarassed to take the names of people who have troubled you if you know them, name the business and companies that have caused you distress if you can, and feel free to share any photos and videos you have of these people. It would also be an excellent idea to pass on this evidence to local authorities such as the police. Again, this may or may not be of use, but who knows? It's worth trying.

7. Don't let such experiences shake your confidence or self-esteem. It's normal to be upset and frightened and horrified and even traumatised, but if possible, don't let it harm your opinion of yourself and who you are.

That's all I have to say.

I totally agree that itâ€™s not entirely safe for solo travelers from foreign nations or even Indians themselves, but there are some basic rules of thumb you can follow to avoid more than 90% of such incidents:
1. Avoid booking hotels below $60 per day, as these are often not properly regulated. Given the large number of budget hotels in India due to the population, these cheaper options are usually unfairly managed and more prone to incidents  (we ourselves do not choose to stay at these places). The same applies to restaurants always check reviews on Google before visiting. Aim for restaurants rated $$ or higher on Google Reviews. These options are much less likely to encounter any such issues. Best is to choose well know hotel chains : Leela, Taj, Oberoi, Marriott. For budget travels Zostels are decent as well. Book your hotels online from known websites rather than through a travel guide. 
2. Itâ€™s best, best to just ask an Indian (your neighbor even if you barely know them) in whichever country you are in to help you with the travel. As an Indian, I can say we love to share our culture, and we are just waiting for you to ask us for help with your India travels. You can even ask that colleague/friend/neighbor of yours if they know someone in the cities youâ€™re visiting who can guide you to good places, restaurants, and experiences.
3. Avoid booking through travel websites or tour agencies. This is one of the worst ways to travel in India, as most of these guides, as you mentioned, have commissions tied to specific hotels, restaurants, attractions or literally anywhere they take you to. 
4. Choose cities or areas within cities that are comparatively safer. For example, in my personal opinion (not to say other areas are unsafe), In Mumbai, areas from Bandra to Churchgate/Malabar Hill are the safest, and these are the areas where most of the good restaurants and places to visit are. So, you can book a hotel in any of these areas.
5. Use Uber for cabs, a bunch of other helpful apps like Blinkit (for a 10-15 minute delivery of literally anything even a TV at your place). 

6. Research thoroughly before your trip. If you are traveling with a decent or above-average budget, it will likely be safer and more comfortable than traveling on a tight budget.

Manusmriti and Its Discriminatory Principles Against Women
Manusmriti, an ancient Hindu text, is often criticized for its regressive stance on women. It institutionalized the idea of patriarchy, placing women under the authority of male figures at all stages of lifeâ€”father in childhood, husband in adulthood, and sons in old age. Women were denied independence and were considered secondary to men. The text explicitly mentions that women should not study the Vedas, thus barring them from accessing knowledge and spiritual growth. Moreover, it portrays women as inherently weak, untrustworthy, and incapable of self-governance, which led to centuries of gender inequality and suppression in traditional Hindu society.

Manusmriti and the Marginalization of Shudras
Manusmriti also laid down a rigid caste hierarchy that placed Shudras, the so-called lower caste, at the bottom of the social order. It denied them access to education, religious practices, and basic rights. The text imposed severe penalties on Shudras if they even attempted to learn or recite Vedic scriptures. Here is my true thoughts to share about my country (Pros and Cons and tips for better experience):

India is a great country like every other but as you shared the experience, there are dangerous areas and the thought of our people are still at a stage where it may be normal for us but for you is a threat.

If you wish to travel and part of India, book through proper guide and make sure to spend money on a good tour package (India is cheap in terms of price but you will get quality as you spend more.) If traveling alone then plan ahead and plan accordingly (always be prepared for problems and take step by step action).

India is a safe country as long as you stay in areas where we Indians stay and not venture into unsafe areas we do not go.

Know that police is not 911 and emergency no. Varies from area to area. So keep a note.

Find a local Indian who you can trust online. We Indians will help always so reach out to us. 

There are many Indians like me who would help you have a comfortable stay and travel in each and every town. So dont be shy to reach us.

1) Say â€œNOâ€ STRONGLY. People will always wanna sell you and ask photos just say NO in a string voice and a few times.

3) Bargain Bargain & Bargain. Its a must needed skill (if cant find a trustworthy local to help you with.) 

4) Everything has a tag called MRP which is the maximum price to sell stuff. If you buy something without MRP its either not mainstream, orginal or home made. So buy stuff with MRP (clothes, accessories and everything has MRP even food.)

5) Food is clean everywhere. But have medication as even we Indians get food poisoned in US/Europe or elsewhere due to change in food.

High pressure sales is something you really have to watch out for on package tours. 

I found this out the hard way. I recently went on holiday to Cairo and some spots down the Nile. Like in this video, it was a package tour with flights, accommodation, transfers and activities sorted. One of my complaints before we left was that the itinerary was quite vague, often saying something like "explore the great pyramid before doing some cultural activities in Cairo". It turns out that "cultural activities" means that you will be taken to various shops and pressured into buying their products. It was really disappointing as 1) the reason we booked the package tour was to avoid these situations and 2) I thought we were going to be diving into the history and culture of Egypt. Instead it seemed to be an opportunity for our guide to have a break, while we were forced around a shop, shadowed by a salesman. These salesmen would use a lot of cheap tricks, for example if you stopped to look at something, they would put it behind the counter, "saving it for you", to pressure you into a purchase. They would not make the prices clear, especially for single items, often using the excuse that "they would come up with a price for ALL the items we were going to pick out, once we had finished shopping". And that was in proper shops. That's before we talk about the gauntlet of street salesmen that you were forced to walk through, coming into and out of attractions. 

I was "lucky" enough to experience this as part of a group tour, so at least the high pressure sales were spread over a group of people. I can only imagine what it was like as a solo traveller. Thank you Phoebe for bringing these practices to light!

I was asked to cook by a hotel owner and to serve him water during the peak of the pandemic. I was trapped with them and they took the opportunity to humble me. 
I was paying full price at his hotel where he had no other guests because of the pandemic. Im a woman with a very respectable financial standing and this was very jarring experience. Since they controlled food during the pandemic if i didnt pander to their expectations, they would not give me food. I remember being willing to tip people generously just to stop hassling me. I had to pay the price for being a woman that had a level of financial affluence without paying the toll for violating their social norms. 

The government official who administered my vaccine misbehaved with me. I could do nothing without having an instance of SH and it affected me to my very core. There's this dull feeling of resignation when the body goes into survival mode when this happens over and over.

I had a landlord in one of those apartments who was my protector. He made some passes, but very respectfully and told me as I left that I should never return without a male figure. I thanked him because he had looked out for me. 

It was an 8 month long nightmare. My family had left the country but I had an Indian passport and couldnt leave with much ease. I also lost emotional strength and faculties during that stressful phase. 

You made an effort not to hurt people's sentiments while being in excruciating pain yourself. I appreciate it but that takes a heavy emotional toll. Truth is, that is a culture which coddles its men. There should be economic consequences, these are natural consequences.

I eventually purchased a Privilege visa and guaranteed that I would always have another option I could reliably fall back on if there were yet another unforeseen crisis. 
I remember thinking to myself, well death is inevitable but id like to age and pass in a society where I do not feel such an intense alienation towards, not to mention feeling hunted, intruded upon and watched. It has definitely impacted how I relate with men, both from my culture and others.

In Himachal Pradesh, they would matter of fact open my Amazon packages and refuse to pick up my garbage. 

What you said about the sense of relief when you left resonated. I had to sleep for four months and could hardly work, so I requested time off and my clients understood. It took me 14 months to stop being worried that someone would enter my apartment in the next country I now live in. When i shared my concerns in this new country, people are simply amazed that I would even have such a concern. 

Ive been reflecting on my sense of identity, belonging and self worth as it pertains to the country I was born in. 
I question if unconditional loyalty is owed to any system one may belong to where one had no choice. I will change my passport for cathartic reasons. I also plan to lobby for extending refugee visas for Indian minority women so more women who want to live peaceful lives outside can have options availavle to them.

It is an incredible country with a powerful past but I should not have to carry such a heavy weight to accommodate a society I find harder and harder to understand. That the burden should be on you, or on me to communicate effectively while being traumatized and violated is a tad bit excessive.

My experiences as a native Indian: (note: The average north indian is the most hospitable person you can get and are really friendly and helpful. So not dissing the average person. I may not be the most adventurous person)

The rest of India is simply more calm and far less overwhelming than the North. The cities are less populated than the north. The ppl are a lot less aggressive and pushy. The scams are lesser than the north (not zero. There's a lot here too. Just lesser). This is something my north indian peers say too. 

Our family's personal experience in Rajasthan: 
We stayed at reputed 4 star hotels throughout the trip. The staff at the hotels were very good. The forts are epic. The Udaipur cruise was awesome. The Rajasthani food is good. 

The problems: We Indians know the art of bargaining and knowing when to spot scams like Pashmina etc etc. We know that tourism guys like cab drivers can be pushy. But even for us it was getting overwhelming. 

We hired a driver via the hotel from Jodhpur to Jaipur. He was nice at first, but highly aggressive later. He wasn't listening to our parents request to drive calmly. His conduct at petrol stations was shady as heck. We were relieved when we reached Jaipur. The agency associated with the Jodhpur hotel that gave the driver apologized and gave us other drivers for Jaipur. The hotel was wonderful. But the first Jaipur driver was highly pushy. He wasn't wanting us to go to Bapu Bazaar which is a beautiful Bazaar. He was pushing us to go to a mall which we weren't interested. We had to be assertive. 

The 2nd driver wasn't pushy but he was unfriendly. 

At Udaipur, the drivers were quite aggressive. This sullied our trip there a bit. It gave a bitter taste. The mistake we made: hiring drivers at the airport in Udaipur, and continuing with the agency from Jodhpur. 

My tips when visiting India: 

Stay at reputed hotel chains like Taj, Ibis, Fortune etc. Don't go to unknown hotels. 

Use guides/drivers from the hotels. Don't use unknown agencies. Even though they maybe more expensive, it helps

Do thorough research. Put your foot down when the driver doesn't want to take you to places you want to visit. Don't let the drivers  dictate how the trip should go. Inform the hotels if you feel uncomfortable. 

Don't fall for scams. If you want to do shopping, shop at places you've researched and feel comfortable. 

Don't indulge in too many conversations outside of the travel related stuff. It can easily get dicey. 

Don't allow auto/cab guys to bring others into the vehicle. 

Be vigilant throughout the journey. Observe the drivers conduct. Walk out if unsafe after pending money settlements. 

Keep cash. It helps. Also keep food poisoning medicines ready.
